Award.AwardTitle: EARS: Paving the way to dynamic spectrum sharing: Understanding regulatory and enforcement mechanisms

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective:
The objective of this program is to help eliminate key barriers to implementing new spectrum sharing policies though the development of regulatory and enforcement mechanisms that protect incumbents users. The proposed research develops needed enforcement mechanism though developing algorithms for rapid identification and location of users, developing metrics appropriate for enforcement systems, and determining fundamental limits for density of nodes to achieve reliable detection for enforcement. The technology development will be guided by considering legal issues surrounding privacy and whether the technology requires changes to existing telecommunication policy.

Intellectual merit:
The intellectual merit is the discovery of novel approaches to transmitter identity and location verification, and the development of metrics that regulators can use to help determine compliance of future spectrum sharing systems.

Broader impacts:
The broader impacts are elimination of roadblocks to spectrum sharing mechanisms. The President?s Council of Advisors on Science and Technology identified nearly 1GHz of spectrum that can be shared to spur the economy and establish the United States as the leading technology innovator for dynamic spectrum access. Understanding the technical viability, legal feasibility, and system costs of spectrum sharing enforcement will eliminate fear, uncertainty, and doubt on the part of spectrum owners about moving into a spectrum sharing mode. Our approach also proactively reaches out to the regulatory community and educates them on the new regulatory approaches and enforcement mechanisms made possible by this research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In recent years, starting with the advent of smartphones, there has been an ever-increasing demand for data rates and quality wireless services. Efficient spectrum utilization is key to meet this demand. Efficient spectrum utilization will also have far reaching economic benefits. Dynamic spectrum sharing, has been recognized by several researchers as a way to efficiently utilize spectrum. Current spectrum regulations make it impossible to dynamically share spectrum (with an exception of the recently opened 3.5 GHz band). New frameworks, policy, regulations, and their enforcement mechanisms needs to be evolved by regulatory bodies (such as FCC, NTIA). The outcomes of this project act as enablers for regulatory bodies to take informed decisions to develop policies to roll out frameworks for dynamic spectrum access, with a comprehensive background on how enforcement mechanisms can be implemented. 

                This project outlines spectrum enforcement strategies and a framework for an automated enforcement system. We developed strategies for quantifying the success of the enforcement system, and metrics on the duration and the detriment caused due to non-compliance based on the enforcement system parameters. This project further develops a clear definition of the spectral efficiency in the new paradigm of spectral use, based on the wireless network parameters. A novel spectrum efficiency metric is formulated and analysis on the benefits it brings as compared to traditional metrics. This will potentially aid in developing frameworks for dynamically allocating spectral resources. We further demonstrate the importance of radio receiver performance metrics and their utility in spectrum allocations for efficient spectrum utilization. Through this project we investigated the importance of several metrics and their impact on spectrum sharing. We envision that the work carried out in this project will not only pave way for several regulatory policies and frameworks but also will lay down the foundations for developing metrics associated with dynamic spectrum access.
